title: Why was inbreeding tolerated in medieval European royalty? - Quora

response.answer_text: 2 reasons 1st point; It’s not that bad Hold on, before you down vote me to oblivion, I’m not advocating incest, im merely stating facts. The “inbreeding” you think of was mostly arranged from distant cousin marriages. These really aren’t so bad, and have numerous advantages royalty would have seen good in a marriage. The first is genetic sexual attraction: Though it wasn’t very known back then, distantly related people will feel sexual attraction to each other, especially if they’ve never met before. In most noble marriages back then, the bride and groom never met each other until the wedding day. Now, this isn’t always the case, I’m generalizing. 1a) The genetic lottery; Royalty were generally taller and fitter in the time. If you breed two related people, there is a chance you might just get that one in a million child, who gets perfect family characteristics. There is a reason animal breeders often inbreed. It is not completely negative. Inbreeding heightens the effects of both positives and negatives. Breeding two royal family members means they both have the positive effects. This is why sheep breeders use inbreeding (not sibling breeding)quite often. We can see this in the hapsburgs. Because of their tendency to marry in the family, they all got that horrendous jaw. This is because a great majority of the ancestors have this trait. That was an example of a negative effect of inbreeding, but there were plenty of positives. For example, if you have a family that has a tendency to make tall children, a tall father and a tall mother from the same royal family, you get a really tall child, due to many tall ancestors. The child will also have a distinct look, resembling both the father and the mother due to both having similar ancestors. Thats a good thing, right?(ignore the hapsburgs) I’d just like to mention that said cousin marriages weren’t as common as you may think. They weren’t common at all, and were relatively rare. It would take multiple generations of cousin marrying to be truly “inbred”(like the hapsburgs) My 2nd point is that all breeding is inbreeding. All humans are distantly related to each other, some just more related than others. Obviously, siblings are the most related. The “inbreeding” we see in royalty isn’t like that. Well, egyptian royalty did have a few sibling marriages, but thats not medieval. (Again, Im not trying to advocate incest, just stating fact) Edit: Let me specify what I mean by “inbreeding.” specifically when I said “cow and sheep breeders”. I don’t mean sibling or niece/nephew breeding, I mean more like distant common ancestor. A great example of this distant cousin marrying is King Ferdinand of Aragon and Queen Isabella of Leon and Castille. Both members of the Royal House of Trastámara. (apologies for the Wikipedia citation, its just so terribly convenient) They were distant kin. So, their issue are “inbred” right? But… did we ever hear about that? Not as much as the hapsburgs famous inbreeding. Granted, the hapsburgs were a lot more incest-like. Still, why ignore one and chastise the other? If incest is so bad, surely all counts are the same. Ps.. Take a shot every time I mention the hapsburgs P.p.s Hapsburgs aren't completely medieval. Their heyday was in the renaissance.

In Spain, marriages within the 4th degree were banned between 1550 and 1917, the so-called Consanguinity Laws. Different countries started to ban such things at different moments and to a different degree. And these differences exist even today. At most places, “inbreeding” in the sense of something truly illegal only prohibits full siblings or parent-offspring, i.e. spouses with 50% degree of relationship (basically a simple estimate for the fraction of DNA that is identical for the two people). Note that clones and identical twins have 100%, full siblings have 50%, parent-offspring also have 50%, grandparent-grandkid have 25%, and there are other percentages. The royal families generally liked inbreeding at some moments – first cousins etc. – and it may have good reasons. When the genes are taken “really from the family”, that could have guaranteed the most aristocratic genes for the kids. And this argument is surely correct to some extent. Some problems may arise and have arisen but it’s questionable whether the negatives exceed the positives when an aristocratic house considers itself – or is considered – as really special. Today, most people would say that the inbreeding is just bad, even for cousins or 2nd cousins etc., and the desire to preserve the aristocratic genes should be secondary (or, more radically, the special nature of these families is a superstition). But most of the contemporary people say so mostly because they’re not aristocrats and they have been taught to despise aristocracy – or at least not consider aristocrats as exceptionally good people. Things were different centuries ago. Aristocrats surely considered themselves special most of the time; and so did most of their subordinates, in fact. Even though the consanguinity laws were active at most European countries, the royal families often got exceptions directly from the Pope which was enough.
